Scott Stirling wrote:

> ....Some of my thinking has led to a similar thought, and a
> question: like Serializable, Runnable, Cloneable, etc. I have been
> toying with what a Testable interface could do.  What would it be like
> to idiomaticize Testability as a marker interface in Java?
>
> One idea is that "implements Testable" could mean that a runtime flag
> could be used to enable/disable a set of test methods (a la JUnit's
> test**** method naming pattern) in classes.  Just a thought.

Heck of a thought.

I would expect:
   a) The class structure would contain the test methods, but they
       wouldn't be loaded in the absence of a -test flag, or some such.

   b) With the -test option present, a framework would exist to help you

        experiment with the APIs, uncovering gaps in the documentation.
        (If I give an empty string as an argument, do I get a null
String, an
         empty string, or an exception?)

   c) API documentation would have a link to a page containing test
       methods that would exist only if the class was testable.

Such a thing could be really cool, self-documenting addition to
libraries.

Interestingly, in considering such a thing, I realize that the tests
will tend
to be class-based, in such a scenario, rather than package-based. That
brings back some previous discussions about how tests should be more
oriented towards "basic operations" than "class methods".

And that thought brings back the famous game show line:
    "Will the real unit testing please stand up?"

What the heck *is* unit testing, anyway? If it is "class methods", then
JUnitDoclet made sense. But if it is "basic operations", isn't that more

like integration testing? Or is there a middle ground, say, as package-
level operations?

Right now, I'm seeing "unit" as one or more of:
  * method
  * class
  * package
  * use case

Are there any other candidates? Are any of these automatically
ruled out? What exactly does the word "unit" mean, in this
context?
